awd_titl_txt: Statistical Advances for Intensive Categorical Spatiotemporal Data from an Eye-Tracking Technique
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will develop methods for analyzing eye-tracking data that will provide a more accurate view of the underlying cognitive processes of human behavior. Eye movements tend to track with attention, and eye-tracking is a flexible tool for tracking eye movements. Despite the ubiquity and utility of eye-tracking methodology, current data analytic practices are limited. The methods to be developed are general and may be used to advance knowledge in other fields where comparable data are collected. The investigators will apply the new methods in interdisciplinary collaborative efforts with researchers from psycholinguistics, education, and computer science. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in these analytic techniques, and the results of this project will be disseminated to both specialized and multidisciplinary communities through journal articles, conferences, workshops, and a webinar. All findings, data, code, and software from this project will be made publicly available. 

This research project will develop statistical models for intensive categorical time series data with the complex temporal, spatial, and dependence structures exhibited by eye-tracking data. The investigators will develop a general class of models called dynamic generalized linear mixed effect models or dynamic GLMM. These models will capture both temporal effects (serial dependence and trend effects) and spatial effects (spatial dependence and distance effects) while accounting for multiple forms of variation across data modes including trials, items, persons, item groups (or clusters), and person groups. The investigators will present a dynamic GLMM specification for binary data, which will indicate whether the participant is or is not fixating on a critical interest area at each moment in time. The investigators also will present a dynamic GLMM specification for ordered-category or partially ordered category data using an IRTree approach. This approach allows the researcher to examine cognitive processes which drive the choice among multiple stimuli for the eye to fixate on. To improve data analytic practices, methods using the dynamic GLMM will be developed following the sequence of the data analytic procedures: data description, model specification, model estimation, model selection, and model evaluation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
We provide statistical methods for the analysis of intensive categorical (binary and multicategorical) temporal-spatio data from eye tracking. To the best of our knowledge, the statistical methods we propose are the first attempt to model multiple sources of data complexity from eye-tracking data. We anticipate the proposed approach to model building will enhance the data analysis practice. Results from simulation studies will provide guidelines for data analyses. The proposed methods have been disseminated to audiences in psychometrics, educational psychology, cognitive neuropsychology, computer science, and psycholinguistics. The results of this research were published in journals, books, and on our websites, and have been presented at multidisciplinary conferences such as annual meetings of the Psychometric Society, the Cognitive Science Society, the Society for Human Sentence Processing, the American Educational Research Association, and the National Council on Measurement in Education. All code and data we used in the published work were released in the Open Science Framework website or in the online supplementary materials.

 

Intellectual Merit

Eye-tracking is a flexible tool that allows the researcher to study multiple species (humans, primates), multiple developmental stages (infants, elderly adults), populations that vary among multiple dimensions (neurotypicality, brain damage, education, literacy), in order to ask and answer fundamental questions about how individuals think and behave in different contexts. While eye-tracking data provide a dense and rich source of information about real-time cognitive processes, current data analytic practices for eye tracking data do not take full advantage of this information. The proposed research has the potential to advance knowledge of ongoing cognitive processes during a variety of cognitive tasks where eye-gaze provides a window into cognition. The proposed statistical methods can be used to explain or predict the effects of external events on eye-gaze, providing insights into ongoing cognitive processes. The project will allow researchers across a variety of fields - to make better use of the incredibly rich source of information that the eyes provide about cognition. The developed model will be of a general form that can inspire extensions to other types of intensive categorical time series data with complex temporal, spatial, and dependence structures across a variety of disciplines.

 

Broader Impact

The methods developed through this award will support the sophisticated analysis of eye-gaze data both in the field of psycholinguistics, as well as broadly across fields where eye gaze is used as a window into cognition. The analysis of eye movements can have broad impact to society in that it can provide insight into how people understand conversation. It can tell us about when and why language processing is impaired in special populations. It can be used understand why some media or advertisements are more enticing than others, or what makes a TSA screener more likely to notice a weapon. The huge range of applications for eye-gaze technique means that it could potentially impact a wide range of disciplines, including in health, education, technology, public safety, and so on. The techniques that we developed are offering researchers, across these varied disciplines, better tools for asking and answering the fundamental questions that their field is interested in.

The methods we developed for intensive categorical time series data (model specification, estimation methods, model selection, and model evaluation) are general, and can be used to advance knowledge in other field when comparable data are collected. The data structures that we worked with are common in studies that employ the visual-world paradigm, which is a dominant technique for the study of language processing in multiple literatures including philosophy (Sedivy, 2007), child developmental disorders (McMurray et al., 2010), cross-cultural psychology (Barrett et al., 2013), human?computer interaction (Qu& Chai, 2007), human?robot interaction (Staudte & Crocker, 2011), and surgery and medical education (Merali, Veeramootoo, & Singh, 2019). Thus, the methods that we developed to work with these data structures will be of interest across a wide range of fields.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 04/24/2023
Modified by: Sun-Joo Cho
